Utah‚Äôs Supreme Court rejects appeal to overturn congressional map with Democratic-leaning district
description: Utah‚Äôs Supreme Court rejected on Friday an appeal by Republican lawmakers and left in place a congressional map that gives Democrats a high chance of picking up one of the state‚Äôs four Republican-held...
fullText:
SALT LAKE CITY (AP) ‚Äî Utah‚Äôs Supreme Court rejected on Friday an appeal by Republican lawmakers and left in place a congressional map that gives Democrats a high chance of picking up one of the state‚Äôs four Republican-held U.S. House seats in the fall.

In the order signed by Chief Justice Matthew B. Durrant, the court explained that they do not have ‚Äújurisdiction over Legislative Defendants‚Äô appeal.‚Äù

The lawmakers had appealed a decision in November in which a Utah judge adopted a congressional map creating a Democratic-leaning district over one poised to protect all four of the state's U.S. House seats held by Republicans.

The map keeps Salt Lake County almost entirely within one district, instead of dividing the heavily Democratic population center among all four districts, as was previously the case.

Republicans have argued the court does not have legal authority to enact a map that wasn‚Äôt approved by the Legislature.

Utah‚Äôs Republican Senate President Stuart Adams pushed back on the ruling, saying the ‚Äúchaos continues."

‚ÄúWe will keep defending a process that respects the Constitution and ensures Utah voters across our state have their voices respected,‚Äù he said in a statement.

Katharine Biele, president of the League of Women Voters of Utah, one of the plaintiffs in the lawsuit, applauded the ruling.

‚ÄúWe are encouraged that the court dismissed this improper appeal and allowed the process to move forward without disruption to voters or election administrators,‚Äù she said in a statement.

The redistricting stems from an August decision in which Judge Dianna Gibson struck down the Utah congressional map adopted after the 2020 census because the Legislature had circumvented anti-gerrymandering standards passed by voters.

The ruling pushed the state into a national redistricting battle as President Donald Trump urged Republican-led states to take up mid-decade redistricting to try to help the GOP retain control of the House in 2026.

The approved map gives Democrats a much stronger chance to flip a seat in a state that last had a Democrat in Congress in early 2021.

Emma Petty Addams, co-executive director of Mormon Women for Ethical Government, another plaintiff in the lawsuit, said in a statement Friday that ‚Äúthe courts have provided an important check on the Legislature, affirming the people‚Äôs constitutional right to alter and reform their government.‚Äù

The ruling comes weeks before the deadline to file for reelection.

There is another appeal pending in federal court that was spearheaded by two of the state‚Äôs Republican members of Congress. The lawsuit filed in February argues the state judge violated the U.S. Constitution by rejecting the congressional districts drawn by the Republican-led state Legislature.

title: Backstreet Boy Brian Littrell dealt legal blow in fight against woman he claims trespassed on his private beach
description: Brian and his wife, Leighanne Littrell, first took legal action against Carolyn Barrington Hill in September 2025.
fullText:
Brian Littrell‚Äôs $50,000 lawsuit against the woman he claims trespassed on his private beach property has been dismissed by a Walton County, Fla., judge.

According to court documents obtained by Page Six, the judge dismissed the case ‚Äúwithout prejudice‚Äù on Tuesday for ‚Äúfailing to state a claim for which relief can be granted.‚Äù

However, Brian and his wife, Leighanne Littrell, have 20 days to refile an amended complaint for their case.

A rep for Brian and Leighanne did not immediately respond to Page Six‚Äôs request for comment.

The couple first took legal action against Carolyn Barrington Hill on Sept. 19, 2025, accusing her of seven counts of illegal trespassing, one count of invasion of privacy and one count of stalking over incidents that took place between April 2025 through September 6, 2025. However, they later dismissed their count of stalking.

They claimed in their legal filing that Hill ‚Äúignored the no trespassing‚Äù signs on their Santa Rosa Beach property and entered the area ‚Äúwithout right or authority.‚Äù

They alleged that Hill ‚Äúset out to antagonize, bully and harass‚Äù them with her ‚Äúmultiple‚Äù ‚Äúunauthorized entries‚Äù that started in April.

Brian and Leighanne further claimed that they suffered ‚Äúemotional distress‚Äù because Hill‚Äôs ‚Äútrespassing‚Äù hindered their ‚Äúuse and enjoyment of the property.‚Äù

In the judge‚Äôs order, Littrell‚Äôs claim for emotional was dismissed because ‚Äúemotional distress damages are not permitted on a claim for trespassing.‚Äù

Brian and Leighanne also listed their BLB Beach Hut LLC as a plaintiff, and as a legal entity and not a person, it cannot experience emotional distress, according to the judge.

In one incident the pair accused Hill of setting up her own beach furniture on their property before she engaged in a heated exchange with their property manager.

The lawsuit alleged that Hill started ‚Äúshouting and cursing‚Äù at their property manager after he asked her to move her things.

They also claimed she ‚Äúvideotaped‚Äù them without their ‚Äúknowledge or consent‚Äù and ‚Äúincited‚Äù other members of the public to join her in her alleged trespassing of their property.

In addition to Hill, the Littrells also named the Walton County Sheriff‚Äôs Office in their suit for allegedly failing to enforce their private property rights.

title: How much snow will New York City get? Latest inch count predictions
description: The National Weather Service says "significant to major accumulations looking more likely" for Metro New York area. Here are the latest inch counts.
fullText:
New York City appears to be in for its second major snowstorm this winter.

The latest forecast from the National Weather Service calls for a nor'easter this weekend, showing the Metro New York area is in for anywhere from 9 inches in New York City to a foot of snow way out on the tip of Long Island.

"A widespread accumulating snowfall is expected, with significant to major accumulations looking more likely, especially closer to the coast. Blizzard conditions are possible across Central and Eastern LI," the NWS said.

The entire region is under a winter storm watch from Sunday, Feb. 22 into Monday, Feb. 23.

SAN ANGELO, Texas (Concho Valley Homepage) ‚Äî The Angelo State Rams stay in the win column Friday night (video courtesy of Brian Cunningham).

After a 3-3 start, the Angelo State Rams have found their groove with a five-game winning streak. Following their four-game sweep over the Sul Ross State Lobos last weekend, the No. 11 Rams picked up right where they left off Friday.

Angelo State quickly gained momentum in the bottom of the second inning, scoring four runs followed by three in the fourth, five in the fifth and one in the sixth, respectively. Austin Beck led the team with four RBI, going 4-for-5 at the plate. Beck leads the Rams as well with a whopping .891 slugging percentage through 11 games this season.

The Rams look to defend their home field twice in Saturday‚Äôs doubleheader. Game one begins at 4 p.m. while game two follows at 7 p.m. CST.

title: Prep sports recap for Feb. 20, 2026
description: PEORIA, Ill. ‚Äî Metamora, Pontiac and Illini Bluffs punched their tickets to the girls basketball sectional round with regional championships on Friday. Baylie Nena scored 19 points to lead Metamora to a 62-28 win over Morris in the class 3A regional title game the redbirds hosted. Metamora earned its first regional championship since 2010 and [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
PEORIA, Ill. ‚Äî Metamora, Pontiac and Illini Bluffs punched their tickets to the girls basketball sectional round with regional championships on Friday.

Baylie Nena scored 19 points to lead Metamora to a 62-28 win over Morris in the class 3A regional title game the redbirds hosted. Metamora earned its first regional championship since 2010 and will play at the Galesburg sectional Tuesday.

Pontiac beat Monticello, 38-35, to win the class 2A Fairbury regional. Pontiac, which won its first regional title 2009, advances to play at the sectional which it will host Tuesday.

Illini Bluffs defeated host Elmwood, 49-41, to win a class 1A regional. The Tigers, who were led by Anabelle Reimer‚Äôs 12 points, advance to the Macomb sectional next week.

Boys basketball winners on Friday included Normal Community, Morton, Dunlap, Dee-Mack, Tremont, LeRoy, and North Fulton.

At the state wrestling meet, five area wrestlers advanced to the state finals matches on Saturday. Olympia‚Äôs Connor Collins (106 pounds), Canton‚Äôs Connor Williams (285), Washington‚Äôs Wyatt Medlin (165) and Josh Hofer (215) and Morton‚Äôs Harrison Dea (132) won their semifinal matches Friday to move into Saturday night‚Äôs championship round at State Farm Center in Champaign.

title: Amerks honor 1996 Calder Cup championship team
description: ROCHESTER, N.Y. (WROC) ‚Äì The Amerks honored members of the 1996 Calder Cup Championship team on Friday night as Rochester took on Laval. Dixon Ward, Wayne Primeau and Jody Gage greeted fans, who had the opportunity to take a photo with the Calder Cup. The trio also reflected on their days in Rochester.
fullText:
ROCHESTER, N.Y. (WROC) ‚Äì The Amerks honored members of the 1996 Calder Cup Championship team on Friday night as Rochester took on Laval.

Dixon Ward,¬†Wayne Primeau¬†and¬†Jody Gage greeted fans, who had the opportunity to take a photo with the Calder Cup.

The trio also reflected on their days in Rochester.

‚ÄúI loved my time in Rochester,‚Äù Ward said. ‚ÄúWinning the Calder Cup was still the most exciting time I ever had in the game, including the Stanley Cup final. We didn‚Äôt win it, so it comes second.‚Äù

Primeau reflected on the team‚Äôs championship run.

‚ÄúAnytime you can win a championship, it‚Äôs a great feeling,‚Äù Primeau¬†said. ‚ÄúFor me, that year, I came from junior, finished the last eight games of the regular season, and then played 17 of the 19 playoff games. Great, great crowd, great attendance. Just an amazing atmosphere, and I‚Äôm so, so happy that we were able to finish it out with Game 7.‚Äù

The 1996 championship is the last Calder Cup that belongs to the Amerks. As the final weeks of the regular season wind down, this year‚Äôs team will look to bring the trophy back to Rochester for the first time is 30 years.

title: NFL combine is awash with questions about veterans, not rookies. They range from Lamar Jackson to Maxx Crosby
description: While the veteran news and ramp up to free agency will cast a long shadow in Indianapolis, it won't eliminate a litany of prospect-related storylines that will get rolling once workouts begin.
fullText:
Maybe it‚Äôs the quarterback chaos or the landslide of head coaching changes. Or because it‚Äôs late February and many of the NFL‚Äôs personnel departments already seem satisfied that the No. 1 overall pick in the draft is in the barn. Or maybe it‚Äôs because the 2025 season produced a wildly unexpected Super Bowl between the Seattle Seahawks and New England Patriots, and an even more unexpected Super Bowl quarterback winner in Sam Darnold.

Whatever the driving force, it‚Äôs thrusting the usual sideshow of the NFL scouting combine ‚Äî trade rumors, free-agency buzz and clandestine general manager meetings ‚Äî into the middle of the main stage. And with that, the college players who are taking their next big step toward draft positioning have become a subplot.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going to be a wild offseason and it‚Äôs going to start next week [at the combine],‚Äù one prominent NFL agent said this week. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs so much more than usual with different veteran stuff compared to how guys are going to work out ‚Äî and we have a good class of guys [in the draft]. All the quarterback things to figure out, some of the [veteran] defensive players ‚Äî some of the young players that could be traded with the staff changes ‚Äî there‚Äôs going to be a lot going on. ‚Ä¶

‚ÄúI see you guys talking about storylines ‚Äî when was the last time anyone checked in on what‚Äôs going on with Lamar Jackson [and the Baltimore Ravens]? It‚Äôs like that situation has gotten lost in all this noise. That‚Äôs how crazy next week is going to be, though.‚Äù

In fairness, Jackson‚Äôs potential extension deadline ‚Äî spoken into existence by Ravens owner Steve Bisciotti in January ‚Äî has been a prominent story over the past month. Indeed, it will crank up next week, with the quarterback and franchise having been in a contract talks window for several weeks by the time Ravens new head coach Jesse Minter and general manager Eric DeCosta meet with the media in Indianapolis. It‚Äôs expected there will be some kind of temperature gauge coming out of the combine, with the front office and ownership wanting to sign an extension with Jackson and lower his $74.5 million salary cap hit in 2026.

Of course, Jackson is only one of multiple pressing maneuvers ‚Äî or non-maneuvers ‚Äî heading into the combine that will certainly drain some of the daily news thunder from draft prospects‚Äô workouts. Among the prominent:

Who will be getting the franchise tag applied to them before free agency, with the biggest potential name being Dallas Cowboys wide receiver George Pickens. As it stands, Dallas is expected to tag Pickens prior to the March 3 deadline and then either attempt to retain him or try to engage in a sign-and-trade scenario. With Pickens wanting to get to free agency and a likely $35 million average salary per season, there will likely be sparks in a tag scenario.

Potential veteran trades, including Las Vegas Raiders defensive end Maxx Crosby, Philadelphia Eagles wideout A.J. Brown, Miami Dolphins quarterback Tua Tagovailoa, Arizona Cardinals quarterback Kyler Murray and others. Throw in some young players who might get a call or two just to see if they are available on the trade market, including Buffalo Bills wideout Keon Coleman, Jacksonville Jaguars wideout Brian Thomas Jr., Indianapolis Colts quarterback Anthony Richardson and Minnesota Vikings quarterback J.J. McCarthy.

The future of Aaron Rodgers will be a pressing question for the Pittsburgh Steelers ‚Äî at least as it pertains to the organization‚Äôs other options and what kind of timeline there would be for a Rodgers decision. It‚Äôs possible we exit the combine under the presumption that the Steelers are going to move forward and try to find their future QB, which would shift the Rodgers conversation back to the Vikings, whom he was interested in before landing in Pittsburgh last offseason.

And finally, one very big nugget that has yet to be developed: How much interest there will be in Malik Willis in free agency and what the money could ultimately look like. The ballpark speculation in the agent community is some kind of two-year deal averaging $30 to $35 million a season with $40 to $45 million guaranteed. That would put Willis in position to go back to the table next offseason and negotiate a longer term deal that tacks on to the end of 2027 and extends his guaranteed money out into a three-year window through the 2028 season. There are varying opinions on the numbers and structure, not to mention the potential interest. Willis feels like the first big quarterback domino that has to fall in March to trigger a larger migration. If he were to land in Pittsburgh, that then puts Rodgers ‚Äî if he still wants to play ‚Äî onto the market for the Vikings or any other suitors. And once Willis is off the board, the teams that ultimately don‚Äôt have him as an option will then have to reassess.

There‚Äôs a sliding scale of a trade likelihood for all these players. Crosby‚Äôs situation with the Raiders, from what Yahoo Sports has been told by league sources familiar with their talks, is still at a standstill ‚Äî but also not unrepairable. Part of the Raiders‚Äô motivation is to see what Crosby‚Äôs trade market looks like and also where he is at with the franchise in a new phase of a rebuild. The market will likely be the driving force here. If there is a solid offer of draft picks on the table, a trade seems more likely than not.

The same goes for Brown and the Eagles, although it remains to be seen what general manager Howie Roseman could engineer to fill his No. 1 wide receiver spot if there is ultimately an attractive offer available for Brown. It‚Äôs highly unlikely the Eagles would move Brown and not have another player in the mix, so the combine‚Äôs wide receiver workouts and other available players at the position could factor.

The Murray and Tagovailoa process is going to depend on suitors and money. Right now there are zero indications of an appetite to take on either Tagovailoa or Murray‚Äôs remaining contract in a trade, let alone surrender any meaningful draft assets to make him a starter. That could change if the QB shuffling doesn‚Äôt break right for some teams and desperation enters the scenario. Lest anyone forget, there was a market (albeit diminishing) for Russell Wilson the past two offseasons. So there can certainly be a market for Tagovailoa or Murray if a situation gets bad enough.

As for the young players, Coleman seems likeliest to be traded, given the comments of Bills owner Terry Pegula that essentially branded him as not being the front office‚Äôs draft choice. Unfortunately for Buffalo, Coleman‚Äôs trade value will be nothing more than a late pick at this stage. Even with his youth.

Thomas, Richardson and McCarthy are not expected to be officially on the trade block, but all three could garner some interest and calls. Thomas seems less likely to be dealt with the Jaguars moving Travis Hunter primarily to cornerback. McCarthy won‚Äôt be dealt unless the Vikings are presented with a quarterback option that effectively renders any chance of him having a future as moot. And Richardson doesn‚Äôt have much of a market, and will have only one year left on his rookie deal once his fifth-year option is ultimately declined. That doesn‚Äôt leave much room to develop him for any interested franchise. But again, we don‚Äôt know how desperate the quarterback field gets.

That‚Äôs a lot of veteran questions and potential developments that will hang over the primary reason teams are in Indianapolis next week: To begin laying down the foundations of their draft boards for April‚Äôs selection process in Pittsburgh. While the veteran news and ramp up to free agency will cast a long shadow in Indianapolis, it won‚Äôt eliminate a litany of prospect-related storylines that will get rolling once workouts begin.

Here‚Äôs a look at some of those that will be worthy of watching.

While it‚Äôs not expected to be as top-heavy as the 2024 wide receiver class ‚Äî which saw seven first-round picks at the position ‚Äî the wideouts are considered a spot that is going to have depth and offer needy teams quality options potentially into the third round. The general consensus at this point is that four to five receivers could go in the first round. Most of the intrigue will be how the top of the class sorts itself between the trio of Ohio State‚Äôs Carnell Tate, Arizona State‚Äôs Jordyn Tyson and USC‚Äôs Makai Lemon.

‚ÄúI think you could see some [changes in that trio] between interviews, measurements and whatever work gets done,‚Äù one NFC talent evaluator said. ‚ÄúThe medicals, too ‚Äî definitely the medical for Tyson. ‚Ä¶ And it depends how you want to use them in your scheme. Lemon, some teams might not like the size but others might love the versatility and how he catches it. How fast will Tyson run and some of the speed and agility things with Tate will be important. They‚Äôre all good players, but there‚Äôs definitely some of the [Travis] Hunter, [Tetairoa] McMillan, [Emeka] Egbuka [conversations from 2025] because they‚Äôre not all similar players.‚Äù

As it stands, Tate appears to stand out among talent evaluators as the most ‚Äúclean‚Äù player from the threesome, in terms of the total package of consistency, health, size and production. But there‚Äôs definitely curiosity about what his pure speed and agility will look like, especially alongside Lemon and Tyson. Some of those questions will be answered ‚Äî if all three actually do full workouts at the combine, which isn‚Äôt guaranteed. Beyond that trio, there will definitely be some gravity toward the next tier of WRs in Washington‚Äôs Denzel Boston, Tennessee‚Äôs Chris Brazzell II and Notre Dame‚Äôs Malachi Fields, who all bring prototypical ‚ÄúX‚Äù receiver size to the table. The Bills will be an interesting team to watch with that group.

For only the second time in 13 years, we could end up seeing only one quarterback selected in the first round. With the Las Vegas Raiders expected to take Indiana‚Äôs Fernando Mendoza with the No. 1 pick, it‚Äôs also trending toward Mendoza passing on everything at the combine and opening the floor for the rest of the class. That will be a solid opportunity for multiple players, including Alabama‚Äôs Ty Simpson, Penn State‚Äôs Drew Allar, Miami‚Äôs Carson Beck, LSU‚Äôs Garrett Nussmeier and others.

It‚Äôs simply not a great class when it comes to star power (that will come in 2027), but there could be a bit of developmental depth with some strong showings.

Even with the thin class, there is still plenty of quarterback need across the league ‚Äî and that will point plenty of eyes in the direction of Simpson. He was a prospect with some solid draft heat near the midpoint of the college season, but red flags began to get raised as he got knocked around and turned the ball over later in the schedule and then suffered a rib injury that knocked him out of the College Football Playoff. Right now he‚Äôs likely to land in the late first to mid-second round range, somewhat similar to how teams were looking at Bo Nix in 2024, and Jaxson Dart and Tyler Shough last year. If Simpson can wow teams in interviews and put up a good workout, he can build momentum to move up the board and get a QB-needy team to expend a first-round pick on him. Already, you hear his name connected a lot to the Los Angeles Rams, who have the 13th and 29th overall picks.

As for the rest of the pack, it‚Äôs unclear what Allar will be able to do at the combine due to an ankle injury that ended his 2025 season. He‚Äôs the player with the size and easy arm strength, so he‚Äôll draw in someone believing they can home his considerable talent into consistent results. Same goes for Beck, who also has size and arm, but also some leadership and love-for-the-game questions that teams want to pick at in interviews. Not to mention some bad turnovers in important spots, going all the way back to his time at Georgia. Then there‚Äôs Nussmeier, who some evaluators once believed could develop into a first-round pick, maybe even a solidly high one, before injuries derailed much of his 2025 college season. He‚Äôll be another player who draws plenty of eyeballs.

It‚Äôs a loaded class with edge players, with an onslaught at that position expected to end up packing the first round. While there‚Äôs still a lot of work ahead, it wouldn‚Äôt be surprising to see as many as eight edge rushers come off the board in the first 32 picks. A lot of the attention will go to potential top-10 picks in Texas Tech‚Äôs David Bailey, Ohio State‚Äôs Arvell Reese and Miami‚Äôs Rueben Bain Jr. But there will be a battle to figure out the stack after that trio, with players like Auburn‚Äôs Keldric Faulk, Missouri‚Äôs Zion Young and Miami‚Äôs Akheem Mesidor battling it out. Young is a player to keep an eye on. He had a great week of practice at the Senior Bowl and ended up as the game‚Äôs defensive MVP, giving him a lot of buzz coming into the combine. But top to bottom it‚Äôs going to be great draft for teams that need edge players and defensive line talent in general.

‚ÄúIt might be one of the deepest [edge] classes ever, especially through the top 50, 60 guys [in the entire draft],‚Äù an AFC general manager concluded. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs all types of skill sets and body types that fit different needs, but the talent in general just very, very good. There‚Äôs really not a Myles Garrett or Nick Bosa, but there‚Äôs a half dozen guys who could become just good, core second-contract players for teams.‚Äù

Beyond the defensive line, there‚Äôs strength in the class of safeties and cornerbacks as well, with as many as a half dozen or more picks in the secondary likely to land in Round 1. And while safety isn‚Äôt traditionally a position that sees multiple first-round selections, this will almost certainly be one of those years, with Ohio State‚Äôs Caleb Downs, Toledo‚Äôs Emmanuel McNeil-Warren and Oregon‚Äôs Dillon Thieneman all having the profile to possibly land in the first half of the first round. That just doesn‚Äôt happen. Downs in particular will be very intriguing. His r√©sum√© is the kind that he‚Äôd be an easy top-five pick if he played at a more premium defensive position ‚Äî and there were times that some evaluators believed he could even be worth that kind of juice in this draft. The overall strength of the defensive class at premium positions is likely to push him down the board, but it‚Äôs certainly not lost on front offices that so many of the NFL‚Äôs best defenses now feature a dynamic safety like Downs. That could cement Downs higher on teams boards by April.

The next running back after Notre Dame‚Äôs Jeremiyah Love is going to be an interesting development to watch. Overall, the class isn‚Äôt amazing and it‚Äôs going to be dinged a bit by the free-agent class being so strong. There‚Äôs no doubt that some teams want to see what Love‚Äôs backup for the Fighting Irish, Jadarian Price, does in the workouts. As much as game tape matters, Price could have transferred elsewhere for the 2025 college football season and doubled his touches while positioning himself to challenge Love as this year‚Äôs top running back. Now he comes into the draft with less wear and tear but also some curiosity about whether he can be a centerpiece starter and also catch the ball consistently out of the backfield. His workouts will matter, especially as it pertains to his receiving ability. If he can showcase that and put up the type of athletic numbers that some think he can, there will likely be more Alvin Kamara comparisons to follow. As of now, I‚Äôm not sure how that framing works without the receiving end of his game being more proven.

Oregon tight end Kenyon Sadiq is going to be interesting. Some evaluators like him as almost a hybrid running back/wide receiver if he fits into the right scheme. Others see him as a plus-level athlete whose ‚Äúexpected‚Äù 6-foot-2, 240-pound size is going to make him a bit of a tweener ‚Äî and not in a good way ‚Äî in the NFL. There‚Äôs curiosity about Sadiq‚Äôs true height and weight and what his workouts look like. There‚Äôs little doubt he has mismatch potential and maybe some considerable ceiling with the right coach and scheme, but some evaluators don‚Äôt see him as the kind of tight end who can fit in a lot of different places and be on the field at the rate of a multitude of TEs from last year‚Äôs draft. He can‚Äôt be compared realistically to the bigger bodied guys like Colston Loveland and Tyler Warren. And his overall consistency of college production wasn‚Äôt in the realm of Brock Bowers going into the 2024 draft. Who is the realistic comparable at the NFL level to Sadiq and what coach can draw that unique talent out of him?

title: Country Day boys basketball rolls past Newman to win district title
description: Country Day looked like a real state championship contender on Friday.
fullText:
METAIRIE, La. ‚Äì The Country Day boys basketball team certainly looked like a team that‚Äôs capable of repeating as state champions on Friday night.

The Cajuns topped Newman 86-48 to clinch the District 10-2A title. KB Brewer had a game-high 24 points while Curtis McAllister finished with 21.

Country Day led by six at the break but outscored the Greenies 30-6 in the third to create serious separation.

The playoff brackets will be released on Monday.

Edna Karr closes out the regular season with a 46-39 win over De La Salle

Country Day boys basketball rolls past Newman to win district title

title: Brawl between No. 18 Saint Louis and VCU leaves Rams with only 4 players on court
description: Saint Louis ended the game on the rare basketball power play.
fullText:
No. 18 Saint Louis ended its 88-75 win over VCU on a power play Friday, thanks to a wild brawl shortly before time expired.

The fun began with Billikens guard Quentin Jones trying to dribble out the clock with his team up by double-digits. VCU's Nyk Lewis apparently wasn't happy about that, as he stole the ball, took a few steps and jacked up a half-court shot, which resulted in SLU star Robbie Avila ‚Äî you might remember him from his time at Indiana State ‚Äî bumping him out of bounds.

Avila was called for a foul and also received a hard shove in the back from VCU forward Barry Evans, who then got shoved by Jones. Cue the benches the clearing, with 1.1 seconds left on the clock.

BENCHES CLEAR IN SAINT LOUIS ü§Ø VCU AND SLU BRAWL ON THE COURT pic.twitter.com/IRZHItxY7L

‚Äî A10 Talk (@A10Talk) February 21, 2026

The courtside angle of the chaos:

Go Billikens, great win. Barry Evans, what gives bro? pic.twitter.com/QpTqH9PD0h

‚Äî Ross Chaifetz (@RossChaifetz) February 21, 2026

After a lengthy delay, the officials ejected Evans and Jones with flagrant 2 fouls and also ejected all the players who left the bench once the dust-up started.

That left VCU with only four players. Lewis hit his three free throws, and the game ended.

Curiously, it's the second straight year in which a VCU-Saint Louis game saw a brawl break out.

Both sides downplayed the incident after the game, with Avila saying "That's not who we are" and "there's no ill intentions between anybody, just the emotions of the game."

VCU head coach Phil Martelli Jr agreed:

‚ÄúI think there‚Äôs certainly a healthy intensity, as there should be at the top of the league, right? We've got a lot of respect for them. I think they have some respect for us, I assume,‚Äù Rams coach Phil Martelli Jr. said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs two tough teams, two very competitive teams, two physical teams. Stuff like that, you wish it didn‚Äôt happen but, yeah, it‚Äôs an intense game. It‚Äôs an emotional game.‚Äù

Saint Louis head coach Josh Schertz said the incident would "get blown out of proportion," then provided his own recap of the incident:

"Guy stole the ball, Rob didn't take too kindly to it, fouled him, then that guy didn't take too kindly to Rob fouling him, two-hand shove in the back. And then our guy shoved that guy back and everybody just milled around and did what the general basketball fighting does, which is everybody's trying to get held back so they don't have to do anything."

The win keeps Saint Louis in the driver's seat in the Atlantic 10. Friday's game was between the No. 1 and No. 2. teams in the standings, and improved the Billikens' conference record to 13-1 while VCU sits at 12-3.

title: Junior Blues take down the Wildcats in a thriller
description: TOPEKA (KSNT) ‚Äì The classic Washburn Rural and Hayden girls duel didn‚Äôt disappoint. The Junior Blues outlasted the Wildcats comeback efforts to snap a three game losing streak against Hayden in a 40-38 win. Washburn Rural held a two-point lead after the half. Hayden‚Äôs Emberly Connell would steal the ball out of Maddie Vickery‚Äôs hand [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
TOPEKA (KSNT) ‚Äì The classic Washburn Rural and Hayden girls duel didn‚Äôt disappoint.

The Junior Blues outlasted the Wildcats comeback efforts to snap a three game losing streak against Hayden in a 40-38 win.

Washburn Rural held a two-point lead after the half. Hayden‚Äôs Emberly Connell would steal the ball out of Maddie Vickery‚Äôs hand to cut the deficit 18-16.

Hayden would come back from being down 11 points with six to go in the game, to trail by just three with seconds remaining.

Washburn Rural junior Maddie Vickery returned to the court Thursday night following an ACL injury.

She handled her return with poise, finding her offensive rhythm in the second half and finishing with 11 points.@LadyBluesBB @VickeryMaddie https://t.co/GboGItSaGQ pic.twitter.com/i0B5zBTVD0

‚Äî KSNT 27 Sports (@KSNTSports) February 20, 2026

The Wildcats‚Äô Lauren Borjon would try and tie the game with a three point shot but would be fouled, sending her to the line. She went 1-3 at the line, missing the first, banking the second and purposely missing the third to try and get a Hayden rebound.

The Junior Blues would hold onto its lead and secure a win, and snap Hayden‚Äôs 19-game home win streak.

title: Former Bengals great Willie Anderson to undergo kidney transplant
description: Former Bengals offensive tackle Willie Anderson shared in a video via Twitter/X that he's set to undergo a kidney transplant in early March.
fullText:
Former Cincinnati Bengals offensive tackle Willie Anderson shared in a video via Twitter/X that he's set to undergo a kidney transplant in early March.

Anderson said he was diagnosed with kidney disease 10 years ago. He said his girlfriend is a match for a transplant.

Anderson added that he wants to bring awareness to younger players about the harm painkillers can do.

"I never wanted everyone calling me feeling sorry for me," Anderson tweeted. "I wanted to give happy news."

Earlier in February, Anderson¬†reacted¬†with class by congratulating the Pro Football Hall of Fame class of 2026, despite the fact that he fell short again of the 80 percent of the vote required for election.

Anderson automatically is among modern-era finalists in 2027 after finishing as one of the top seven finalists in this year's vote.

Anderson has been a Pro Football Hall of Fame¬†finalist¬†each of the past five years.

This article originally appeared on Cincinnati Enquirer: Willie Anderson, Hall of Fame finalist, to undergo kidney transplant

title: WWE SmackDown 2/20/2026: 3 Things We Hated And 3 Things We Loved
description: On a night that saw more Elimination Chamber qualifiers, here are three things we hated and three things we loved about the 2/20/26 episode of "WWE SmackDown!"
fullText:
Welcome to Wrestling Inc.'s weekly review of "WWE SmackDown," the show that spent this week sending a pair of "WWE NXT" graduates to Elimination Chamber! We'll talk about one of those here in the column, along with Tama Tonga's win over Ilja Dragunov, Cody¬†Rhodes' backstage confrontation with¬†Sami¬†Zayn, and much more!

If you're wondering why we're not discussing Oba Femi vs.¬†Kit Wilson, or Tiffany¬†Stratton vs. Alba Fyre (just to give two examples) it's because this show is three hours long and we can't cover everything ‚Äî that's what our "SmackDown" results page is for. This column's subject material is reserved for matches and segments that moved us in some way, either positive or negative, as we continue to navigate the Road to¬†WrestleMania. So without further ado, here are three things we hated and three things we loved about the 2/20/26 episode of "WWE SmackDown!"

I have spent more time brainstorming creative ways to say "I don't care" than I have actually caring about the Wyatt Sicks and the MFTs' feud.

How long have these two factions been feuding? Weeks? Months? Maybe even years? Regardless, even as the MFTs attempted to turn a new leaf with Tama Tonga's match against Ilja Dragunov (and "attempted" is the operative word here; Solo Sikoa is still walking out with Uncle Howdy's iconic lamp), we still find ourselves in Wyatt Sicks/MFT purgatory. Aside from Sikoa stealing Howdy's lamp, nothing about this feud has changed people. Nothing about this feud has changed. The world of professional wrestling is supposed to be dynamic ‚Äî the card is, famously, subject to change. How can a professional wrestling storyline remain so incredibly static?

First off, I applaud Tonga getting a win over Dragunov. I don't particularly love the call, but I can realize that it's because of my own Dragunov biases. Dragunov will be fine after this loss; in all honesty, Tonga stands to gain more from a win over Dragunov, rather than the other way around. Tonga is the one in more desperate need of a momentum push, which is exactly what a win over Dragunov would give him...if WWE actually moved his character, or any of the MFTs characters', forward, past their relationship with the Wyatt Sicks. I know that Ilja tried to jump the MFTs all on his own after the match, but let's be real: that's not leading to a feud, not if the ending vignette with the Wyatt Sicks says anything about it. Tonga got a momentum-building win, but with no trajectory for him to move towards, what good is a boost?

What good is a boost for any of these guys, MFT and Wyatt Sicks both, if they have nowhere to go? I don't care how cool you look walking to the ring with your arch nemesis' stolen lamp, or how creepy you are with a jumpscare at the end of your vignette. If you're doing the same thing, week in and week out, with no narrative progression other than a title change, I don't want to hear it. It sucks so bad, because the Wyatt Sicks and the MFTs are, on paper, good ideas. The Wyatt Sicks was the most anticipated stable in wrestling, and had the potential to be an incredible, living honor to the late Bray Wyat. The MFTs had the opportunity to be a dominant force on the blue brand, similar to Roman Reigns' original Bloodline. Instead, they're caught in this endless cycle of lukewarm conflict against each other. The narrative stagnation is choking them out like vines. Nothing changes. These men are wasted.

Tama Tonga beat Ilja Dragunov this week and although it came with a heap of help from the MFT, it continues what appears to be a genuine effort to build him up as a credible singles competitor. That may turn out to mean nothing in the grand scheme of things, but for the wishcasting of this writer. However, with the spotlight came quite a uniquely fought bout between Tama and the "Mad Dragon."

No one could ever rightfully call a Dragunov match clean, with his entire attraction being the untempered violence he dishes out and endures. And Tama has very clearly packed a lot more meat onto his frame, while still seeming to move like he did when he was smaller. So everything had a little more weight behind it, everything had a little more ugliness, and personally that only added to the quality of the match.

This wasn't an instant classic between two technical magicians, but it was a fight and interference aside it served both competitors very well. It does put a little bit of a dampener on things that Tama needed help to get the win. The argument on the other hand would surely be that Dragunov needed protecting. But at the end of the day Tama got the win and continues to roll through former United States Champions, having beaten Shinsuke Nakamura earlier this month. And that seems to put him in the trajectory for challenging for singles gold.

I have long been a fan of Tama and while the creative behind MFT leaves much to be desired, it's just cool to see that he may be getting the opportunity to progress for himself. Guerillas of Destiny/Sons of Tonga had been a great act for well over a decade, mostly through Tama's doing, and one could argue he deserves his HBK moment. However that may come.

It's great to see Jade Cargill get some television time on this edition of "SmackDown", but if we're being honest, that television time wasn't really put to good use.

Cargill's promo felt incredibly basic, brief, and by the book. It was nothing more than Cargill essentially saying that she was ready for whoever her WrestleMania 42 opponent, whether it's Liv Morgan choosing to face her as the winner of the 2026 Women's Royal Rumble or the winner of the 2026 Women's Elimination Chamber Match. While it can be argued that this promo was used to set up some mystery intrigue as to who Cargill will face, I would say that's both a good thing and a bad thing. It does generate hype and excitement for the fans, but at the same time, it leaves a whole lot of questions and creates some confusion for me personally.

Cargill's staredown with Charlotte Flair on the entrance ramp did seem to be a bit of a tease and would indicate a potential meeting between them at WrestleMania 42, but at the same time, Flair lost her Triple Threat Elimination Chamber Qualifier to Kiana James which seems to rule out that possibility. It's always possible that Flair could turn on Bliss to cost her the match and maybe take over her place, but I'm not convinced that WWE would be willing to do something like that. Morgan has also been set up as another potential opponent for Cargill, but it seems more likely than not that she'll be picking Women's World Stephanie Vaquer given their recent heated confrontations on "Raw". WWE could also opt to have Tiffany Stratton win the 2026 Women's Elimination Chamber match to set up a WrestleMania rematch between Cargill, but that feels like a really boring and safe choice.

With so many potential opponents for Cargill and with so much uncertainty as to which route WWE will go for her WrestleMania 42 opponent, I can't help but get the feeling that perhaps WWE doesn't quite know which route they want to go down themselves. It feels so convoluted and murky as of this moment, although time will ultimately tell how things will play out.

So Kiana James getting the win over Charlotte Flair and Nia Jax, two well-established names, in a qualifying match for the Women's Elimination Chamber, gave a little of both in that respect. It is just a throw-away match on a Friday "WWE SmackDown" and it is hardly a sign that she is going to main event WrestleMania. But it is also a pin on Charlotte Flair, in a really inventive way too, that also saw her beat Nia Jax ‚Äì a dominant former champion ‚Äì to her first Elimination Chamber match.

That at the very least says the company has faith in James and gives her an opportunity to make a name for herself in the Chamber match on a PLE. And considering the depth ‚Äì or lack thereof ‚Äì of the current "SmackDown" women's division, that's certainly a good thing.

The match itself was pretty fun, with each participant offering something different; Flair was the quarterback veteran, Jax was the dominant force and anchor to the action, and James sneaked in where she could and that ultimately paid off. Flair had worked hard to get Jax in a position to beat her, only for James to leverage her submission into the winning pinfall.

That immediately casts James as a would-be dark horse in the upcoming Chamber match. She may not be the one getting the win and going to the "Show of Shows," but there is a strong chance that she gets a pin or two on some of the faves in the match.

We're on the "Road to WrestleMania,", but it's mostly talk and no action. Superstars are mentioning it and commentary is pushing tickets, but the card is coming together at a snail's pace. One would think one of the matches they'd be building towards is a match for the men's tag titles. MFT only won them a few weeks ago, yet no one is challenging for them. In fact, none of the tag teams seem to even care about them. Instead, they are preoccupied by one half of a former tag team. (There's also one less tag team competing for the titles, but I digress.)

Wrestling storylines sometimes revolve around objects like a fan-made bracelet or a lantern. In the case of Johnny Gargano and Candice LeRae, it was a mask belonging to Axiom. Since losing possession of it, Gargano has become depressed and taken up planking (or maybe it's because he regrets his life choices after seeing his former tag partner winning a title on his first night in a rival company). He is often laid out across a storage trunk or the box containing Danhausen or Chris Jericho or EVIL or the Gobbedley Gooker. LeRae is fed up that no one will help her husband. Gargano is depressed and you're laughing? Fraxiom and Motor City Machine Guns are. In their defense, Gargano has been a jerk to all four men and it's understandable.

The men's tag team division on "SmackDown" has been a mess for a while and the "Raw" division barely qualifies as a division. WWE is wasting one of the greatest tag teams of their generation in MCMG. Fraxiom is a great tag team that should be in the title picture. The problem is no tag teams are in the title picture because no one cares. Street Profits are wrestling house shows when they should've never been off TV. As a fan of tag team wrestling, it's frustrating that there's no effort (but WWE has long stopped caring about tag team wrestling). Last year, the tag title match was left off the WrestleMania card and there was a TLC match the following "SmackDown" that proved they deserved a 'Mania match. It seems we're heading towards another year where the titles are left off one of the biggest PLE's of the year.

With how easily WWE moves on from storylines and its characters, something we've sadly seen for Sami Zayn before, I really liked his backstage segment with Cody Rhodes, keeping him hot and at the forefront of fans' minds, especially during the busy WrestleMania season. This short backstage segment made me believe (or at least have hope) that Zayn isn't going to get lost in the shuffle, and on a pretty average episode of "SmackDown" tonight, it's one thing I really liked.

Zayn has been locked in some kind of mini-feud/rivalry with newcomer Trick Williams, which I've mentioned I really like a lot, but that wasn't the highlight of his story tonight. Sure, Williams got in his face there for a second after a brief crash-out following his interaction with Rhodes, but his confrontation with the former Undisputed WWE Champion was the highlight of this. And, it was something that needed to be addressed after Rhodes pinned Zayn in the Elimination Chamber qualifier last week. But, as we all know, it easily could have been something WWE chose to just never address again.

Rhodes appeared to be attempting to cheer Zayn up backstage, but after Rhodes being the one to dash his Chamber dreams last week, I really loved that Zayn wasn't having it. He wasn't all, "Aw, shucks, man, thanks," when Rhodes told him that he shouldn't be ashamed of himself. Zayn was quick to say that he knew that, and it was Rhodes who should be ashamed for stabbing him in the back. Zayn said everything always comes up roses for Rhodes, but for him? He's been trying to finish his story for 10 years, and Rhodes doesn't know what it's like to do the right thing.

That's when things really started getting heated, and Zayn still wasn't having any of it, and had his mini-crash out, slamming stuff around as Rhodes walked away. I didn't love how Zayn apologized to him after his words with Williams, but this was still one of the best things on the show tonight. I'm also not sure if I love Zayn possibly turning heel, but I don't really know if fans would let that work at this point.

I liked that this was simple and that we didn't see Zayn again for the rest of the night. He's involved with himself and his feelings and plans for the moment, and didn't need to get involved with Williams' qualifying match for the Elimination Chamber, or in the main event where McIntyre cost Randy Orton the match, which brought out Rhodes. This was clean, simple, and effective, and I'm glad WWE doesn't appear to be dropping anything for Zayn, at the moment, at least.

Don't miss any of the major wrestling headlines. You can also add us as a preferred search source on Google.

title: Arizona baseball shut out at home to remain winless
description: It‚Äôs only the second weekend of the season, but Arizona is in jeopardy of letting this one get away before it even starts. The Wildcats were shut out 4-0 by UConn on Friday night at Hi Corbett Field. The loss dropped them to 0-6 and extended their losing streak to eight dating back to last [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
It‚Äôs only the second weekend of the season, but Arizona is in jeopardy of letting this one get away before it even starts.

The Wildcats were shut out 4-0 by UConn on Friday night at Hi Corbett Field. The loss dropped them to 0-6 and extended their losing streak to eight dating back to last June‚Äôs trip to the College World Series, which feels like a century ago. It‚Äôs the longest skid since 2014.

‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs just gotten to the point where there‚Äôs a lot of anxiety, whether it‚Äôs new guys or the guys who played a lot here, just trying to do too much,‚Äù UA coach Chip Hale said. ‚ÄúAnd they put so much pressure on themselves. You can almost tell when guys get hits, right? When they get so excited, it‚Äôs like we‚Äôre back in Omaha or something. It‚Äôs just a base hit in game three or four or five. And so I can tell by that that they just are releasing so much anxiety out of their body. So we just got to find a way to get them to relax.‚Äù

Arizona finished with three hits, singles by Andrew Cain and Mathis Meurant and a double by Nate Novitske. Only two of eight baserunners reached third and the team struck out another 10 times, upping the season total to 80 in six games.

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt look ready to hit when we‚Äôre taking some pitches,‚Äù Hale said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre stuck. And that comes from anxiety. In life, anything you do, it‚Äôs hard to do, to be at your best when your body‚Äôs all knotted up.‚Äù

That frustration spilled over into the field, as Arizona was charged with three errors and made several other defensive miscues.

‚ÄúHow that game ended 4-0 I have no idea, we made so many mistakes on defense that are not characteristic of this group,‚Äù Hale said. ‚ÄúHitting is hard, it‚Äôs the hardest thing to do in sports. We can control what we do on defense.‚Äù

The defensive issues and continued hitting struggles overshadowed another solid pitching performance by most of the staff. Owen Kramkowski struck out six over four innings, allowing two runs (one earned), while five relievers combined for 11 strikeouts. That included eight punchouts by a trio of relievers making their UA debuts.

Lefty Maclain Roberts came on with the bases loaded and one out in the eighth and struck out both UConn batters, the first on a nasty slider and the second a fastball down and away. Roberts then struck out the side swinging in the eighth.

‚ÄúWhen you look at his numbers from the preseason, everybody pitches their way in or pitches their way out,‚Äù Hale said of Roberts, a native of New Zealand who pitched the last two years at Pima College. ‚ÄúHe had not pitched his way in. You pitch like that, you‚Äôre gonna get yourself in another game.‚Äù

While the anxiety and frustration is evident, Hale said the effort has still been there. Making sure that remains will be difficult until the wins come.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs tough for the kids,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI know they‚Äôre they want to win for the program, they want to win for the fans. They want to win for themselves. Coach Jerry Kendall was very succinct in what he used to tell us: ‚Äòdisappointed is okay, we just can‚Äôt let them get discouraged.‚Äô They‚Äôre very close. the two words, but there‚Äôs a huge difference. When you get discouraged, it‚Äôs tough to bring them back, but disappointed is okay.‚Äù

title: Fairfield Union survives Bloom-Carroll comeback in dramatic rivalry win
description: Fairfield Union nearly blew a big lead against rival Bloom-Carroll but secured a dramatic 56-55 victory thanks to clutch free throws.
fullText:
LANCASTER ‚Äì What looked to be a blowout for the Fairfield Union boys‚Äô basketball team turned into a nail-biter against rival Bloom-Carroll on Friday, Feb. 20.

The Falcons raced out to a 16-2 lead in the first five minutes of the game, and midway through the second quarter, held a 24-9 advantage. However, the Bulldogs weren‚Äôt about to go down without a fight. They showed a lot of grit and clawed back, cutting the lead to just two points with 17 seconds remaining.

Fairfield Union held off the hard-charging Bulldogs by making clutch free throws in the closing seconds to come away with a hard-fought 56-55 Mid-State League-Buckeye Division victory.

The Falcons were able to keep the Bulldogs just out of reach by making 13-of-16 free throws in the fourth quarter, including four straight in the final 17 seconds. Mason Ailes led the way by going 6-for-6 in the fourth quarter, and sophomore Asa Kline hit the clinching free throws with 13 seconds left.

‚ÄúFree throws are a big part of our practice, and we try to get at least 50 up during practice,‚Äù Ailes said. ‚ÄúWe haven‚Äôt been the best at it this year, but we were able to come through when we had to. When you are up there in pressure situations, you just try to go through your routine, and we were able to knock them down when we had to.‚Äù

More: Fisher Catholic's Hadli Gillum is a sophomore basketball sensation

Fairfield Union coach John Helber said he knew the Bulldogs (12-10, 7-5) wouldn‚Äôt go away, forcing the Falcons (15-7, 9-3) to make their free throws in the end, but he had confidence in his guys when they toed the line.

‚ÄúI have a lot of confidence in our guys at the free throw line,‚Äù Helber said. ‚ÄúAsa and Mason hit the big ones. We practice free throws every day, and we do different things to make them like game situations in case it comes down to that at the end. We knew Bloom-Carroll would make a run. They have great shooters and run their offense well, but we hung in there and made the plays we needed to make. We needed to get this win tonight, and we needed to bounce back and get some confidence going into the tournament, and I think we did that tonight.‚Äù

The Falcons couldn‚Äôt have had a better start to the game, as five different players scored to build a big lead in the first quarter. They led 19-6 heading into the second quarter, but the Bulldogs stayed the course and finished the first half on a 10-2 run to cut the deficit to 28-19.

The Bulldogs kept the momentum going in the third quarter, cutting the margin to 34-31, but Drake DeFazio hit a 3-pointer at the buzzer to give Fairfield Union a 37-31 lead heading to the fourth quarter.

Bloom-Carroll kept chipping away, thanks to nine points from senior guard Caleb Hinkel. The Bulldogs were able to get it to a one-possession game when Hinkel scored on a three-point play, cutting the deficit to 45-42 with just over two minutes to play. However, the Falcons were able to keep them at arm's length by making seven consecutive free throws at one point.

Jayven Griffith had a steal, and Hinkel scored on another three-point play with 17 seconds left to cut it to 54-52 before Kline sealed it with his two free throws.

‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt like how we started the game, but credit to our guys,‚Äù Bloom-Carroll coach Andy Schmitz said. ‚ÄúOur guys want to keep playing, and it showed a lot about who we are. We stayed aggressive and stuck with it. We knew we couldn‚Äôt get it all back at once. It was going to be a grind all the way through, and our guys gave great effort and didn‚Äôt give up and kept fighting to the end. We just weren‚Äôt able to quite get over the hump because Fairfield Union kept making their free throws.‚Äù

Keaton Webb led a balanced attack for the Falcons with 18 points and eight rebounds. Kline finished with 11 points, 12 rebounds, and three assists. Ailes also had 11 points, while Trevor Utzinger chipped in six points and five assists, and Dean Clark added six points.

Hinkel led the Bulldogs with 15 points, Griffith had 13, and Brady Petty chipped in nine points.

Tom Wilson is a sports¬†reporter for the Lancaster Eagle-Gazette. Contact him at¬†740-689-5150¬†or via email at twilson@gannett.com for comments or story tips. Follow him on X at twil2323.

This article originally appeared on Lancaster Eagle-Gazette: Fairfield Union boys' basketball holds off Bloom-Carroll comeback

title: What time is the Winter Olympics closing ceremony? TV schedule, channel to watch 2026 Milan Cortina Games end
description: Here's everything you need to know about the 2026 Olympics closing ceremony, including TV channel and streaming options for the Winter Games conclusion.
fullText:
What time is the Winter Olympics closing ceremony? TV schedule, channel to watch 2026 Milan Cortina Games end originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

Several weeks of historic competition have already flown by, and concluding the 2026 Winter Olympics will be a closing ceremony worth watching.

Spectators around the world have watched as athletes from 93 countries have competed on a global stage in Milan. From intense alpine skiing and snowboarding, to artistic figure skating and even curling, these games have been nothing but pure entertainment.

With events officially wrapping up and medals handed out, it's time to celebrate the accomplishments of athletes and teams alike. The closing ceremony, taking place in Verona, will be a spectacle of grand proportions.

Here's everything you need to know about the Olympics closing ceremony, including TV channel and streaming options for the conclusion of the Winter Games.

The 2026 Olympics closing ceremony will take place on Sunday, Feb. 22, starting at 2:30 p.m. ET. The event is expected to run two and a half hours.

Fans can watch the 2026 Olympics closing ceremony broadcast live on NBC, where Terry Gannon, Tara Lipinski and Johnny Weir will provide commentary. Cord-cutters can stream the pageantry on¬†Peacock.

The NBC-owned streaming service's sports programming features live coverage of NFL Sunday Night Football, the NBA, the Olympic and Paralympic Games, Premier League soccer, Big Ten football and basketball, Notre Dame football, Big East and Big 12 basketball, PGA Tour golf and more.

Fans can also watch the ceremony on DIRECTV Stream, which carries NBC and hundreds of other networks and offers a free trial to new subscribers.

The closing ceremony for the 2026 Winter Olympics will be held at Arena di Verona in Verona, Italy. The venue is steeped in Italian history, as it is a Roman amphitheater from 30 AD.

Gold medalists Hilary Knight (hockey) and Evan Bates (figure skating) will be the United States flag bearers at the closing ceremony.

Both five-time Olympians, they were selected for the honor in a vote of Team USA athletes. It's the first time the U.S. will have two flag bearers at a Winter Olympics closing ceremony.

The closing ceremony for the 2026 Winter Olympics will feature an incredible lineup of performers. International ballet icon Roberto Bolle, Italian DJ Gabry Ponte and singer Achille Lauro are some of the performers expected to appear on the Olympic stage.

The theme for the closing ceremony is "Beauty in Action"

The theme is designed to provide viewers a celebration of "Italian culture, creativity and the unity of sport, art and beauty". It is also said to be curated as a reflection of the connection between Italian mountains and cities.

title: ‚ÄúI Just Crashed My Hellcat‚Äù: LaMelo Ball Gets Courtside Consolation From DaBaby Over Crashing His Hummer
description: Sometimes it‚Äôs not about having the ability to ‚Äúbuy another‚Äù after losing something valuable; it‚Äôs about the loss itself. LaMelo Ball can get his hands on another Hummer, but the one he crashed must have left him feeling devasted.
fullText:
Sometimes it‚Äôs not about having the ability to ‚Äúbuy another‚Äù after losing something valuable; it‚Äôs about the loss itself. LaMelo Ball can get his hands on another Hummer, but the one he crashed must have left him feeling devasted. Or perhaps not, if he thinks like DaBaby.

There were reports from earlier this week that suggested that Ball crashed his Hummer in the streets of Charlotte. Thankfully, he was unharmed. He got into another car ‚Äî notably, a Lamborghini ‚Äî and simply left the scene.

Ball had no time to dwell on that though, with NBA action resuming on Thursday following the All-Star break, and in the Charlotte Hornets‚Äô game against the Cleveland Cavaliers, he got words of consolation from rapper DaBaby.

A Charlotte native, DaBaby was sitting courtside. When Ball came close to him mid-game, he got the star guard‚Äôs attention and reminded him, ‚ÄúN **** crash cars every day, we ain‚Äôt worried about none of that!‚Äù*

Ball heard him, and laughed it off. Although for certain, he won‚Äôt be looking forward to crashing a car every day! DaBaby, however, went on to reveal in the video that, ‚ÄúI just crashed my Hellcat. N **** crash cars everyday.‚Äù*

The video involving the rapper was funny, but in actuality, it was a scary moment for Ball and those involved in the crash in downtown Charlotte. The lady driving the other car, like Ball, escaped without any major injuries which was a moment of relief for the Hornets baller.

After the team‚Äôs loss to the Rockets on Thursday, Ball, who dropped 11 points and had somewhat of an off night, said, ‚ÄúI seen her get straight out of the car.‚Äù

Talking about how he felt in the build-up to the game, Ball added, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just alive and blessed. God is great.‚Äù

For now, there is no verdict on who was at fault, and it is also uncertain whether any legal action will be taken against Ball. He is not expected to miss time on the court, although he appears slightly shaken up.

The post ‚ÄúI Just Crashed My Hellcat‚Äù: LaMelo Ball Gets Courtside Consolation From DaBaby Over Crashing His Hummer appeared first on The SportsRush.

title: Tulare Union girls basketball punches ticket to championship game
description: Tulare Union is the only Tulare County high school to advance both of its basketball teams to the Central Section's championship games.
fullText:
The Tulare Union High School girls basketball team will join the boys squad at Selland Arena next weekend for the 2026 Central Section championships in Fresno.

The third-ranked Tribe girls upset two-seed Atascadero 43-26 in the semifinals on Feb. 20 to earn a trip to this season's Central Section Division IV title game. They will now play No. 1 Torres (24-6) in the championship game.

A day before, the No. 1 Tulare Union boys outlasted fifth-seed Kingsburg 54-50 to punch their ticket to the Central Section Division III final. The section's high school basketball championships will be played on Feb. 27-28.

Tulare Union is the only Tulare County school to advance both of its basketball teams to the section's championship games.

"That's amazing," Tulare Union girls' head coach Monica Diaz said.

In Tulare Union's third straight girls playoff victory, the Tribe (22-7) raced to a 19-1 lead and never looked back.

Senior forward Jazzy Miller led the way with 14 points, scoring four in the first quarter, six in the third, and four in the fourth.

Senior Kayloni Cox netted 12 points, draining three triples.

The Tribe also received points from Karla Gomez (two), Jia Freitas (two), Kaiden Valdez (nine), and DeAwnee Akins (four).

"These kids wanted to win," Diaz said. "They had energy. They wanted to win. They were bringing it. These kids have worked really hard. It all started in the offseason ‚Äî to be able to get to Selland, to be able to have a team that you work with continuously, and get them prepared, get them going, it's special. Our kids are fast."

More: Central Section hoops playoffs see CVC, Tulare Union advance to finals

Tulare Union opened the playoffs on Valentine's Day, defeating No. 14 Reedley 29-24 in the first round. Then on Feb. 18, the Tribe continued the momentum with a 38-31 quarterfinal victory against sixth-seed Templeton.

Tulare Union will be making only its second trip to a section final. In 2023, the Tribe enjoyed a Cinderella run as the 13th seed, advancing to the Division IV section title game, but fell 32-31 to No. 6 Lompoc.

Three years later, Tulare Union is headed back to Selland Arena ‚Äî the home site of the Central Section basketball championships.

"It's truly amazing," Diaz said. "It's surreal."

More: Tulare Union's Brayden Stevenson follows dad's basketball legacy

Exeter 50, Fowler 37: The No. 3 Monarchs (21-11) advance to the Central Section Division VI championship game and will play fourth-ranked Foothill (17-9).

This article originally appeared on Visalia Times-Delta: Tulare Union basketball teams both advance to Central Section finals

title: South Bay Lakers recap: G League Lakers race past Legends
description: The G League Lakers continued to build momentum on Friday with a blowout win over the Legends.
fullText:
After getting eight full days off since their last game, the South Bay Lakers headed to Comerica Center in the Dallas-Ft. Worth Metroplex to take on the Texas Legends on Friday. They're looking to start stacking up wins in bunches as the push for the G League postseason nears.

South Bay put up 37 points in the first quarter and was ahead 66-45 at halftime. The team never let up, as it led by as many as 26 points in the fourth quarter and ended up winning by a final score of 127-105. It was plus-10 in rebounds, plus-seven in fast-break points and shot 51.1% from the field while holding Texas to just 37.7% field-goal shooting.

Drew Timme led the way for the Lakers with 25 points on 11-of-20 shooting, eight rebounds and four assists. Adou Thiero, a rookie forward who was taken in the second round of the 2025 NBA Draft, made all but one of his eight shot attempts and ended up with 19 points and seven rebounds. Four men off the bench ‚Äî Malik Williams, Arthur Kaluma, Anton Watson and Augustas Marƒçiulionis ‚Äî scored in double figures.

Bronny James played 27 minutes in this game and shot 5-of-14 from the field. He finished with 13 points, five rebounds, five assists, one steal and two blocks.

This win gave South Bay a 12-8 record, which puts it in fifth place in the Western Conference.

This article originally appeared on LeBron Wire: South Bay Lakers recap: G League Lakers race past Legends

fullText:
The first game of the spring for the Dodgers is finally here on Saturday afternoon, with a bus ride to Tempe to face the Angels at Diablo Stadium.

Yoshinobu Yamamoto gets the start for the Cactus League lid-lifter (hat tip to Bill Plunkett), making what will be his only start before leaving next week to join Japan for the World Baseball Classic. Shohei Ohtani will start at designated hitter in his earliest game action in spring since joining the Dodgers.

Jos√© Soriano will start on the mound for the Angels, who according to Jeff Fletcher of the Orange County Register ‚Äúwill have almost their entire projected everyday lineup when they face the Dodgers in the first Cactus League exhibition game on Saturday,‚Äù though Mike Trout is not expected to start.
